dt: {bc}to provide with something desired, needed, or suited

dt.t: I needed money, and they {it}accommodated{/it} me with a loan.
rebuilt the ship to {wi}accommodate{/wi} the bigger containers
a hotel that can {wi}accommodate{/wi} about 100 people
Investors quickly {it}accommodated{/it} themselves to the new market conditions.
trying to {wi}accommodate{/wi} the special interests of various groups

pt: {sc}adapt{/sc} {sc}adjust{/sc} {sc}accommodate{/sc} {sc}conform{/sc} {sc}reconcile{/sc} mean to bring one thing into correspondence with another. {sc}adapt{/sc} implies a modification according to changing circumstances.
{sc}adjust{/sc} suggests bringing into a close and exact correspondence or harmony such as exists between parts of a mechanism.

pt.t: {it}adjusted{/it} the budget to allow for inflation

pt: {sc}accommodate{/sc} may suggest yielding or compromising to effect a correspondence.

pt.t: businesses {it}accommodating{/it} themselves to the new political reality

pt: {sc}conform{/sc} applies to bringing into accordance with a pattern, example, or principle.
{sc}reconcile{/sc} implies the demonstration of the underlying compatibility of things that seem to be incompatible.

pt.t: tried to {it}reconcile{/it} what he said with what I knew

pt: {sc}contain{/sc} {sc}hold{/sc} {sc}accommodate{/sc} mean to have or be capable of having within. {sc}contain{/sc} implies the actual presence of a specified substance or quantity within something.

pt.t: the can {it}contains{/it} a quart of oil

pt: {sc}hold{/sc} implies the capacity of containing or the usual or permanent function of containing or keeping.

pt.t: the bookcase will {it}hold{/it} all my textbooks

pt: {sc}accommodate{/sc} stresses holding without crowding or inconvenience.

quotes.t: The young-adult horror authors tend to be too busy {qword}accommodating{/qword} MTV attention spans to create vivid personalities …
… a farmhouse that has been redone to {qword}accommodate{/qword} both good English antiques and luxe 20th-century comforts without sacrificing any of its rough-hewn charm.

Although {it}Lost World{/it} was the hottest movie around, we saw it in a chamber of almost laughable minuteness, barely large enough to {qword}accommodate{/qword} nine rows of seats, which were grudgingly padded …
… political authority depended on tribal leadership, and the scholars had to {qword}accommodate{/qword} themselves to it.

et: borrowed from Latin {it}accommodātus{/it}, past participle of {it}accommodāre{/it} "to fit on, apply, make agree, make suitable, adapt," from {it}ad-{/it} {et_link|ad-|ad-} + {it}commodāre{/it} "to lend, hire, put at the disposal (of), provide," derivative of {it}commodus{/it} "convenient, suitable" {ma}{mat|commode|}{/ma}
In part a latinization of Middle French {it}accommoder{/it}; John Palsgrave ({it}Lʼéclaircissement de la langue française{/it}, 1530) renders {it}accommodate{/it} with {it}accommoder.{/it}
shortdef: to provide with something desired, needed, or suited
to hold without crowding or inconvenience
